update.description:
This is a minimal amount of code to get this library started. It's based on [this wiki page](https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/11599873/Ignition+Sensors). And the Gazebo sensors manager.

The goal of this pull request is to have a working camera sensor. Currently there is a stub camera sensor plugin that publishes an empty image.

Some other stuff:

* Added dependency on ignition-common0 for Time
* Use GenerateExportHeader to create a header with visibility macros
* Added interface target `${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME}_headers` to make it easier to get the include directory for generated headers to targets within this project
* Some cleanup in TestUtils.cmake to link using target names instead of library names where possible
update.title: [WIP] Stub code for Manager Interface

pull_request.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: Sounds good for `RunThreads`. For `RunOnce` I added a time parameter f4cefe2. `RunThreads` could call that function to get the time, and then call `RunOnce` with the time it got.
content.html: Sounds good for RunThreads. For RunOnce I added a time parameter f4cefe2. RunThreads could call that function to get the time, and then call RunOnce with the time it got.

content.raw: I think the semantics of a shared pointer are reasonable here. There is one instance of a `rendering::Manager`, it's used in multiple independent places (multiple systems in gazebo), and they all need it to stay alive (to avoid crashing) as long as they're using it.
content.html: I think the semantics of a shared pointer are reasonable here. There is one instance of a rendering::Manager, it's used in multiple independent places (multiple systems in gazebo), and they all need it to stay alive (to avoid crashing) as long as they're using it.

content.raw: Weak pointers sound reasonable. The major caveat is the creation of weak pointers, which can only be done from a shared pointer.
content.html: Weak pointers sound reasonable. The major caveat is the creation of weak pointers, which can only be done from a shared pointer.

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
Is this `Enable` method supposed to accept a `SensorId`, or is it meant to enable/disable all sensors?

If it's global, does `Enable(false);` mean `RunThreads()` continues to do work, but no sensor data is produced?

If a sensor is disabled, should `RunOnce(true)` force sensor data generation anyways? Should `RunOnce(false)` make disabled sensors generate data?
content.html:
Is this Enable method supposed to accept a SensorId, or is it meant to enable/disable all sensors?

If it's global, does Enable(false); mean RunThreads() continues to do work, but no sensor data is produced?

If a sensor is disabled, should RunOnce(true) force sensor data generation anyways? Should RunOnce(false) make disabled sensors generate data?

content.raw: Is this the same name given to `LoadSensor`?
content.html: Is this the same name given to LoadSensor?

pull_request.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw: How do sensors know when it's time to generate data? Is this assuming sensors are updated in real time? What about real-time factor? How about adding a method to this class that sets what the current time is?
content.html: How do sensors know when it's time to generate data? Is this assuming sensors are updated in real time? What about real-time factor? How about adding a method to this class that sets what the current time is?

pull_request.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

pullrequest.title: Manager with Camera sensor and example

content.raw:
A few `Init` functions accept references to `Manager` classes that are expected to be alive for longer than this class is. These references need to be stored for use by this manager in `RunThreads()`. If the rendering and physics managers are destructed before this class then there could be a crash.

How about changing the references to an `std::weak_ptr`? `sensors::Manager` would lock the weak pointer when updating sensors, then release it. Rendering/physics could be safely destructed without risk of a crash here.
content.html:
A few Init functions accept references to Manager classes that are expected to be alive for longer than this class is. These references need to be stored for use by this manager in RunThreads(). If the rendering and physics managers are destructed before this class then there could be a crash.

How about changing the references to an std::weak_ptr? sensors::Manager would lock the weak pointer when updating sensors, then release it. Rendering/physics could be safely destructed without risk of a crash here.
